hints.content:
**Area** is the space a flat shape fills.

To measure area, we can count the number of **same-sized** square units needed to cover a shape. The squares should have **no gaps or overlaps**.

![A square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7e744eac00a89cf4ac865b83356eaf7f0c1de260) is $1$ **square unit** because it measures $1$ unit on each side.

This shape has $12$ square units covering it, not $15$:

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has four squares, the second row has four squares, and the third row has four squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c82e9932413427ea10d9ce56a09b32d1a0998753)

This shape has $9$ square units covering it, not $15$:

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has four squares, the second row has four squares, and the third row has four squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5d69200f571647373549c110b4c2e9978412182b)

This shape has $15$ square units covering it. There are no gaps or overlaps.

![A figure made up of five rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has three squares, the second row has three squares, the third row has three squares, the fourth row has three squares, and the fifth row has three squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/05651b6b324bfd040a976d746f507f6f423d0719)

So, this shape has an area of $15$ square units.

This shape has $15$ square units covering it. There are no gaps or overlaps.

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has five squares, the second row has five squares, and the third row has five squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a8e2ff2142ed183a183301efc6ae93b9b2b5b19a)

So, this shape has an area of $15$ square units.

These shapes have an area of $15$ square units:  

![There are two figures.  The first is a figure made up of five rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has three squares, the second row has three squares, the third row has three squares, the fourth row has three squares, and the fifth row has three squares. The second is a figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has five squares, the second row has five squares, and the third row has five squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/05651b6b324bfd040a976d746f507f6f423d0719) ![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a8e2ff2142ed183a183301efc6ae93b9b2b5b19a)

question.content:
**Which shapes have an area of $15$ square units?**

![A square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7e744eac00a89cf4ac865b83356eaf7f0c1de260) is $1$ square unit.

choices.content: ![A figure made up of five rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has three squares, the second row has three squares, the third row has three squares, the fourth row has three squares, and the fifth row has three squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/05651b6b324bfd040a976d746f507f6f423d0719)))

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has four squares, the second row has four squares, and the third row has four squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/c82e9932413427ea10d9ce56a09b32d1a0998753)

![A figure made up of five rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has three squares, the second row has one square, the third row has one square, the fourth row has one square, and the fifth row has three squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5d69200f571647373549c110b4c2e9978412182b)

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has five squares, the second row has five squares, and the third row has five squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a8e2ff2142ed183a183301efc6ae93b9b2b5b19a)
